docs.lead_paragraph: Women who get pregnant within six months of giving birth are at higher risk for premature babies, low birth weight and infant death, a new study reports. While the association has been reported before, the researchers say they were able to establish for the first time that the risk increases even if the first pregnancy was uncomplicated, and regardless of the mother's socioeconomic status. The report appears in the current issue of the British journal BMJ.
docs.abstract: Dr Gordon C S Smith, Cambridge University researcher, reports in British journal BMJ that women who become pregnant within first six months of giving birth have increased risk of premature birth and neonatal death; risk of premature babies is twice as high and neonatal death is more than three times as high as women who wait more than six months to become pregnant again; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Women who get pregnant within six months of giving birth are at higher risk for premature babies, low birth weight and infant death, a new study reports.    While the association has been reported before, the researchers say they were able to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tests on herbal supplements taken to reduce cholesterol found that half did not contain their listed ingredients or were so badly made that they could not release their contents, a consumer group says. With two products, the pills were so hard that they could be broken apart only with a hammer, said the testing group, ConsumerLab.com.
docs.abstract: ConsumerLab.com president Tod Cooperman reports that tests performed on herbal supplements used to lower LDL cholesterol show over half do not contain listed ingredients or are poorly made so they do not release contents; says that one pill, out of 16 products tested, had to be broken apart with hammer; tests results on guggulsterones, policosanols and sterols studied are on website www.consumerlabs.com (S)
docs.snippet: Tests on herbal supplements taken to reduce cholesterol found that half did not contain their listed ingredients or were so badly made that they could not release their contents, a consumer group says.    With two products, the pills were so hard...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Rich Barbara signed up to test the iBOT -- Johnson & Johnson's stair-climbing wheelchair -- in the summer of 2001, he thought he would be reluctant to give it back at the end of the two-week trial. But impressed as he was with its balancing abilities, Dr. Barbara, a 50-year-old paraplegic, found himself yearning for his manual wheelchair. ''I was glad when my two weeks were up,'' said Dr. Barbara, a clinical psychologist at the University of Pittsburgh's Rehabilitation Hospital.

headline.main: Users Discover Pros and Cons In Stair-Climbing Wheelchair

docs.abstract: Independence iBOT 3000 Mobility System, stair climbing wheelchair able to navigate rough terrain and elevate user, wins approval from Food and Drug Administration; chair, designed by New Hampshire inventor Dean Kamen and produced by Johnson & Johnson, is reviewed by two-week trial user Dr Rich Barbara, who finds some aspects of new chair too cumbersome, outweighing benefits; financing of chair by insurance is discussed; other similar chairs described; photo (S)
docs.snippet: When Dr. Rich Barbara signed up to test the iBOT -- Johnson & Johnson's stair-climbing wheelchair -- in the summer of 2001, he thought he would be reluctant to give it back at the end of the two-week trial. But impressed as he was with its balancing...

docs.lead_paragraph: I thought my husband, Ralph, was having a stroke. What else could cause a healthy 54-year-old man suddenly to become disoriented and confused? More than eight hours after the onset of his symptoms, the attending doctor at our local E.R. diagnosed a very strange disorder -- amnesia -- or transient global amnesia. It is a temporary brain affliction that affects about 23.5 per 100,000 people every year. After a second and third opinion, we were convinced that Ralph had experienced this rare but real phenomenon.

headline.main: Memorable, For the Loss Of Memory

docs.abstract: Candice Reed article gives account of her 54-year-old husband's temporary amnesia; describes onset of problem and diagnosis; Dr Thomas Chippendale, University of California (San Diego) neurologist, reports he sees around 150 cases yearly; disorder generally causes lapse in memory, but does not effect events far removed or immediate recall ability of patient; minor time frame of complete memory loss, possibly a few hours, is common; cause of amnesia is unknown (M)
docs.snippet: I thought my husband, Ralph, was having a stroke. What else could cause a healthy 54-year-old man suddenly to become disoriented and confused? More than eight hours after the onset of his symptoms, the attending doctor at our local E.R. diagnosed a...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who are obese may want to think twice before going to high altitudes. They may be at higher risk for altitude sickness, researchers reported yesterday. Although obese people may by unlikely to go in for mountain climbing, Dr. Tony G. Babb, senior author of the study, said they might put themselves at risk simply by driving too quickly to high-altitude locations.
docs.abstract: Institute for Exercise and Environmental Medicine study, led by Dr Tony G Babb and published in Annals of Internal Medicine, finds that people who are obese are more suseptible to altitude sickness; 78% of overweight men studied developed symptoms of altitude sickness while only 40% of average weight men experienced symptoms; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: People who are obese may want to think twice before going to high altitudes. They may be at higher risk for altitude sickness, researchers reported yesterday.     Although obese people may by unlikely to go in for mountain climbing, Dr. Tony G. Babb,...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: INSTITUTE FOR EXERCISE AND ENVIRONMENTAL MEDICINE

docs.lead_paragraph: Cancer cells usually are not attacked strongly by the body's immune system, in part because they are derived from the body's own cells and because tumors can employ techniques to suppress the immune system. Thus, the goal of a cancer vaccine is to flag a patient's tumor cells as foreign so the patient's own immune system will attack the cancer. This is usually done by injecting cells or proteins from a tumor, often combined with a general immune stimulant. But there are many approaches and animated disputes over which is best.
docs.abstract: Fact that cancer cells are not usually identified and attacked by human's own immune system is primary hinderance in development of cancer vaccine; different theories are presented; companies currently working on vaccines are discussed; groups, such as Antigenics, utilize antigens isolated from patient's own tumors to vaccinate them; CancerVax Corporation is in final clinical trial with vaccine that is made from cultured melanoma cancer cell lines; vaccines appear to effect early stage cancers much more effectively than late stage cancers; cancer specialist Dr Donald L Morton compares arresting late stage cancer to stopping runaway train (M)
docs.snippet: Cancer cells usually are not attacked strongly by the body's immune system, in part because they are derived from the body's own cells and because tumors can employ techniques to suppress the immune system.     Thus, the goal of a cancer vaccine is...

docs.lead_paragraph: When I entered college four and a half decades ago, I was a svelte and firm 108 pounds. But by the end of my freshman year I had acquired 12 pounds of flab, hardly attractive on my five-foot frame. You see, I was raised never to waste food -- reminded daily that the children in Poland were starving -- and faced with family-style meals in the dormitory dining hall, I conscientiously cleaned every platter my table was served, prompting my roommate to nickname me Stuff. That and the cookies I kept in my dorm room spelled my dietary doom.

headline.main: Skipping a College Course: Weight Gain 101

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explores eating habits of college students and gives advice about portion size, food quality, caloric value and eating behaviors in effort to help students avoid unnecessary weight gain; dietitian Ann Selkowitz Litt's book College Student's Guide to Eating Well on Campus is part of suggested campus survival kit; food portions and relative calories are given; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Healing Heartburn,'' by Dr. Lawrence J. Cheskin and Dr. Brian E. Lacy. Johns Hopkins University Press, $17.95. ''Heal Your Headache: The 1-2-3 Program for Taking Charge of Your Pain,'' by Dr. David Buchholz. Workman Publishing, $13.95. Anyone who has popped an antacid after a fiery bowl of chili or who is on a regimen of extra-strength pain relievers for a splitting headache should welcome these books. Heartburn and headache are universal ailments, each life-disrupting. They are also not well understood by the sufferers.
docs.abstract: Book Healing Heartburn by Johns Hopkins University Drs Lawrence J Cheskin and Brian E Lacy defines common, but misunderstood, condition of heartburn; they contend that gastroesophageal reflux disease is primarily harmless to long-term health, but can, in certain serious situations, lead to complications including esophagitis or precancerous Barrett's esophagus; misconceptions about disorder are discussed; Johns Hopkins neurologist Dr David Buchholz's book Heal Your Headache: 1-2-3 Program for Taking Charge of Your Pain offers three-step process to avoid using medication to control headaches; definition of migraines is presented; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Healing Heartburn,'' by Dr. Lawrence J. Cheskin and Dr. Brian E. Lacy. Johns Hopkins University Press, $17.95.    ''Heal Your Headache: The 1-2-3 Program for Taking Charge of Your Pain,'' by Dr. David Buchholz. Workman Publishing, $13.95.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Once children leave kindergarten, they are often not given enough opportunity to go to the restroom in school, creating a problem that can lead to incontinence, a new study reports. Writing in the September issue of The Journal of Urology, researchers reported the results of a survey of 467 elementary school teachers in Iowa on handling students' restroom needs.
docs.abstract: University of Iowa researcher Dr Christopher S Cooper, writing in Journal of Urology, finds that elementary school bathroom privileges are often too strict for child's level of bladder control; asserts that holding off urination can cause other medical problems; contends most teachers are not aware of potential physical harm of making children wait; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Once children leave kindergarten, they are often not given enough opportunity to go to the restroom in school, creating a problem that can lead to incontinence, a new study reports.    Writing in the September issue of The Journal of Urology,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The tragedy was that a boy died. The failure was that the hospital was unable to persuade the parents to donate his organs. The case was being discussed at a weekly meeting of organ-transplant coordinators for the Philadelphia region, the frontline troops in an effort to raise organ donation rates that have not kept pace with the demand for transplants.

headline.main: How Diplomacy in Handling Death Can Save Lives

docs.abstract: Patti Mulvania, Gift of Life donor program's clinical staff development and quality assurance director, explains need for better and more empathic technique in approaching grieving families with prospect of organ donation; New England Journal of Medicine study reports that, only 42 percent of potential donors give organs and that 80% of donations come from 19% of hospitals; many organ donation groups see these statistics as motivation to investigate methods and expand success in getting available organs to thousands who need them; separation between medical staff and organ donation staff is seen to be more beneficial to families trying to make decision on how to proceed; challenges facing donation coordinators and their efforts described; photos (S)
docs.snippet: The tragedy was that a boy died. The failure was that the hospital was unable to persuade the parents to donate his organs.    The case was being discussed at a weekly meeting of organ-transplant coordinators for the Philadelphia region, the...
